column4: What is the best VM software for running ubuntu and fedora on windows? Anyone know?
Well, I have windows vista and I'm not sure of how I should get a triple boot going with fedora and ubuntu (and vista), so somebody suggested that I test with virtual machines
I would use virtualbox - doesn't get any easier, but if you want to triple boot create 3 partitions, install windows 1st and one of the lin distros last so you get the grub bootloader
I'm just not quite sure of which distribution to install first. I'm also not sure how large each partition for the linux's should be (/, /home, /boot)
I would install windows first .. just use gparted from the livecd to create 3 paritions for about how big you think each will be
I already have vista, so should I install ubuntu next, or fedora?
either one - it's not really important since you windows is the only 1 that will screw up grub

Well I already had ubuntu and windows dual-booting with grub, and when I tried to install fedora I got an error every time. That's why I started from scratch with windows only. Is there something special that you have to do to add fedora to vista and ubuntu?
nope ... just 3 different partitions ... maybe your fedora disk has an error ... you can install as many distros as you want on the same hd
So You think that if I just install ubuntu and fedora in the free space with each their own automatic configurations, it should work?
so I have to set up the partitions first? But linux use several partitions, don't they? Like /, /home, /boot, swap?
no - thats the file structure ... just use gparted and manually create 3 paritions, 1 for each distro

So all I have to do is go create an ext3 partition for each linux distribution? And ubuntu and fedora will set up the other logical drives automatically? Do I have to leave some space for that, or will it use the space that I create inside the ext3 partition?
create a partition for both ubuntu and fedora ... installation for each distro will take care of the rest
Alright. Maybe it'll work better if I install fedora first. Ubuntu seems to have more options and seems to be more dynamic during installation. Thank you very much for your help
